parameters.content:
# PROMPT-CHAINING
Prompt chaining decomposes a task into a sequence of steps, where each LLM call processes the output of the previous one.

![Image Description](https://www.anthropic.com/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-cdn.anthropic.com%2Fimages%2F4zrzovbb%2Fwebsite%2F7418719e3dab222dccb379b8879e1dc08ad34c78-2401x1000.png&w=3840&q=75)
## When to use this workflow: 
This workflow is ideal for situations where the task can be easily and cleanly decomposed into fixed subtasks. The main goal is to trade off latency for higher accuracy, by making each LLM call an easier task.

Benefits
- Breaking down the work into simpler chunks, making it easier for each of the LLM to work on.
- Allows for more flexibility, being able to use different model in each stage of a task.
- Easier to debug, as the process is divided into simpler parts.

# ROUTING
Routing classifies an input and directs it to a specialized followup task. This workflow allows for separation of concerns, and building more specialized prompts. Without this workflow, optimizing for one kind of input can hurt performance on other inputs.

![Image Description](https://www.anthropic.com/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-cdn.anthropic.com%2Fimages%2F4zrzovbb%2Fwebsite%2F5c0c0e9fe4def0b584c04d37849941da55e5e71c-2401x1000.png&w=3840&q=75)
## When to use this workflow: 
Routing works well for complex tasks where there are distinct categories that are better handled separately, and where classification can be handled accurately, either by an LLM or a more traditional classification model/algorithm.

# Parallelization
LLMs can sometimes work simultaneously on a task and have their outputs aggregated programmatically. This workflow, parallelization, manifests in two key variations:
## Sectioning: 
Breaking a task into independent subtasks that run in parallel.
## Voting: 
Running the same task multiple times to get diverse outputs.
![Image Description](https://www.anthropic.com/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-cdn.anthropic.com%2Fimages%2F4zrzovbb%2Fwebsite%2F406bb032ca007fd1624f261af717d70e6ca86286-2401x1000.png&w=3840&q=75)
## When to use this workflow: 
Parallelization is effective when the divided subtasks can be parallelized for speed, or when multiple perspectives or attempts are needed for higher confidence results. For complex tasks with multiple considerations, LLMs generally perform better when each consideration is handled by a separate LLM call, allowing focused attention on each specific aspect.

# Orchestrator-workers
In the orchestrator-workers workflow, a central LLM dynamically breaks down tasks, delegates them to worker LLMs, and synthesizes their results.
![Image Description](https://www.anthropic.com/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-cdn.anthropic.com%2Fimages%2F4zrzovbb%2Fwebsite%2F8985fc683fae4780fb34eab1365ab78c7e51bc8e-2401x1000.png&w=3840&q=75)
## When to use this workflow: 
This workflow is well-suited for complex tasks where you can‚Äôt predict the subtasks needed (in coding, for example, the number of files that need to be changed and the nature of the change in each file likely depend on the task). Whereas it‚Äôs topographically similar, the key difference from parallelization is its flexibility‚Äîsubtasks aren't pre-defined, but determined by the orchestrator based on the specific input.

# Evaluator-optimizer
In the evaluator-optimizer workflow, one LLM call generates a response while another provides evaluation and feedback in a loop.
![Image Description](https://www.anthropic.com/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-cdn.anthropic.com%2Fimages%2F4zrzovbb%2Fwebsite%2F14f51e6406ccb29e695da48b17017e899a6119c7-2401x1000.png&w=3840&q=75)
## When to use this workflow: 
This workflow is particularly effective when we have clear evaluation criteria, and when iterative refinement provides measurable value. The two signs of good fit are, first, that LLM responses can be demonstrably improved when a human articulates their feedback; and second, that the LLM can provide such feedback. This is analogous to the iterative writing process a human writer might go through when producing a polished document.

# Agents
Agents rely on LLMs‚Äô abilities to understand complex inputs, reason and plan, use tools reliably, and recover from errors. They typically start with either a direct command or an interactive conversation with the user. Once the task is clear, agents plan and operate on their own, but can return to the user for additional information or judgment. During execution, it‚Äôs important for them to gather real-time feedback (such as tool results or code execution outputs) to monitor progress. They may pause for human input at checkpoints or when facing obstacles. Tasks usually end upon completion, though stopping conditions (like a maximum number of iterations) are often set for control.

Even though agents can manage complex tasks, their implementation is generally straightforward. They are essentially LLMs that loop through tool usage based on feedback from the environment. As a result, it‚Äôs crucial to design both the tools and their documentation with care.
![Image Description](https://www.anthropic.com/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-cdn.anthropic.com%2Fimages%2F4zrzovbb%2Fwebsite%2F58d9f10c985c4eb5d53798dea315f7bb5ab6249e-2401x1000.png&w=3840&q=75)
## When to use this workflow: 
Agents can be used for open-ended problems where it‚Äôs difficult or impossible to predict the required number of steps, and where you can‚Äôt hardcode a fixed path. The LLM will potentially operate for many turns, and you must have some level of trust in its decision-making. Agents' autonomy makes them ideal for scaling tasks in trusted environments.

The autonomous nature of agents means higher costs, and the potential for compounding errors. We recommend extensive testing in sandboxed environments, along with the appropriate guardrails.

parameters.inputText: =Your objective is to clearly understand what kind of content the user expects based on their request: {{ $json.chatInput }}

categories.description: User is asking for a poem on a topic
User is asking for a joke on a topic
User is asking for a story on a topic
If it is not clear what kind of content the user wants.

parameters.text:
=Search for top-rated hotels based on "{{ $json.chatInput }}".  
Provide a concise list including hotel names, price ranges, star ratings, and brief highlights.

Instruction: Always use the SERP API tool.

=Search for top-rated restaurants based on "{{ $json.chatInput }}".  
List 5 recommended restaurants, each with a short description highlighting cuisine type, rating, and popular dishes.

Instruction: Always use the SERP API tool.

=Search for popular tourist attractions and activities based on "{{ $json.chatInput }}".  
Generate a short list including activity names, types (cultural, outdoor, etc.), and brief descriptions.

Instruction: Always use the SERP API tool.

=You are a creative copywriter.
The user wants 3 short, catchy slogans for their brand or product: "{{ $json.chatInput }}".
Emphasize originality, memorability, and brand appeal in each slogan.
Do not include any extraneous details or explanations.

Format your response as follows:
1. ...
2. ...
3. ...

=You are a creative copywriter.
The user wants 3 short, catchy slogans for their brand or product: "{{ $json.chatInput }}".
Emphasize originality, memorability, and brand appeal in each slogan.
Do not include any extraneous details or explanations.

Format your response as follows:
1. ...
2. ...
3. ...

=You are a creative copywriter.

Format your response as follows:

options.systemMessage:
=You are the Email Evaluator for TechSpark

You will receive an email content

Evaluate the email based on:
- Clarity and completeness.
- Tone (professional, friendly, etc.).
- Proper sign-off as "John Doe".
- Text should not include the "Subject"

Return your evaluation as valid JSON with one of the following formats:

1. If the email passes all criteria:
{
  "pass": true
}

2. If the email does not meet all criteria:
{
  "pass": false,
  "feedback": "Provide concise, actionable suggestions here."
}

No extra keys or text outside the JSON structure.

=You are a Customer Support Specialist at TechSpark Solutions.

You will be provided with a customer inquiry

Prepare a concise, polite, and helpful email response addressing the customer‚Äôs question or concern.  

Output only the final email text‚Äîno extra commentary or formatting.



<feedback> (if any)
{{ $json.feedback }}


<preparedEmail> (if an email is already prepared, this is what the feedback is on)
{{ $json.currentEmail }}
</preparedEmail>
</feedback>

options.systemPromptTemplate:
You are a text classifier at TechSpark Solutions.
Please classify the text provided by the user into one of the following categories: {categories}, and use the provided formatting instructions below. Don't explain, and only output the json.

categories.description: Text where the user requests assistance, more information, or expresses a concern about a product or service.
Text that does not ask a question, seek information, or require a direct response.

parameters.text: =List concise, structured key points and angles about the following topic: {{ $json.topic }}

=Using the following notes as a reference:
{{$json.output}}

Create a report outline for "{{$('Prompt Chaining').item.json.topic}}".  
Include clearly named sections with brief descriptions, structured as follows:
- Introduction
- Main body sections
- Conclusion

options.systemMessage:
You are a medical documentation router that determines the appropriate workflow for medical document generation requests.

You will receive patient data and determine what type of discharge letter is needed based on the available information.

Format your response as JSON:
{
  "documentType": "dischargeLetter",
  "department": "[department determined from data]",
  "patientId": "[extracted ID if available]",
  "requiredSections": ["list", "of", "required", "sections"],
  "additionalInstructions": "[any special requirements]"
}

parameters.content:
# Sample Patient Data Input

Provide a sample text file containing patient data in this format:

```
PatientID: 12345
Name: John Doe
DateOfBirth: 15-05-1970
AdmissionDate: 10-01-2024
DischargeDate: 20-01-2024
PrimaryDiagnosis: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus with hyperglycemia
SecondaryDiagnoses: Essential Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia
Procedures: Blood glucose monitoring, Insulin therapy adjustment
Medications: Metformin 1000mg BID, Lisinopril 10mg daily, Atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime
Followup: Endocrinology clinic in 2 weeks
```

This text would be uploaded or entered by the user.

# State Management

This node initializes a JSON structure that will track:
1. Overall workflow state
2. Status of each section
3. Patient data
4. Template information

This state will be updated throughout the workflow.

# LLM Router

This agent determines what type of discharge letter is needed and which sections should be included based on the patient data.

# Ward Documentation Parser

This node reads the ward documentation file from the specified path and parses it into structured data with these sections:

- Demographics
- Admission details
- Diagnoses
- Procedures
- Medications
- Course of treatment
- Lab results
- Follow-up instructions

The parser is designed to handle various text formats commonly found in medical documentation.

# Error Handling

These nodes check if the file was read successfully and handle any errors that might occur during the file reading or parsing process.

# Router Agent

This LLM agent analyzes the patient data to determine:
- Appropriate letter type
- Required and optional sections
- Special instructions based on the patient's condition
- Medical specialty relevant to the case

options.systemMessage:
You are a medical documentation router that determines the appropriate workflow for medical document generation requests.

You will receive patient data and determine what type of discharge letter is needed based on the available information. Analyze the patient's condition, treatments, and department to determine which sections are required in the discharge letter.

Format your response as JSON:
{
  "documentType": "dischargeLetter",
  "department": "[department determined from data]",
  "specialtyType": "[specialty type, e.g., cardiology, orthopedics, etc.]",
  "patientId": "[extracted ID if available]",
  "requiredSections": ["list", "of", "required", "sections"],
  "optionalSections": ["list", "of", "optional", "sections"],
  "additionalInstructions": "[any special requirements based on patient's condition]"
}

parameters.content:
# State Management

This node creates a comprehensive workflow state that includes:
- Patient data organized by section
- Current workflow phase
- Document section statuses
- Template information

This state will be updated throughout the workflow.
